articles.headline: Facing Losses, Billionaire Takes His Own Life
articles.snippet: Adolf Merckle’s speculation in volatile Volkswagen shares pushed his sprawling empire to the edge of ruin.
articles.abstract: Adolf Merckle’s speculation in volatile Volkswagen shares pushed his sprawling empire to the edge of ruin.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT  Adolf Merckle, the German billionaire whose speculation in volatile Volkswagen stock had pushed his sprawling business empire to the edge of ruin, has committed suicide, his family said Tuesday.

articles.headline: Want to Copy iTunes Music? Go Ahead, Apple Says
articles.snippet: Apple said it would begin selling song downloads without anticopying measures and change its pricing structure.
articles.abstract: Apple said it would begin selling song downloads without anticopying measures and change its pricing structure.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  In moves that will help shape the online future of the music business, Apple said Tuesday that it would remove anticopying restrictions on all of the songs in its popular iTunes Store and allow record companies to set a range of prices for them.

articles.headline: In Fed Rate Cut, Fears of Long Recession
articles.snippet: Meeting last month, Fed officials worried that even a dramatic cut in interest rates would not be enough to cauterize the country’s economic troubles quickly.
articles.abstract: Meeting last month, Fed officials worried that even a dramatic cut in interest rates would not be enough to cauterize the country’s economic troubles quickly.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Policy makers at the Federal Reserve appeared almost stunned by an economy that was sinking faster than they had expected on almost every front in December, so much so that they even toyed with the idea of not announcing an official target for overnight interest rates, according to minutes of the meeting released on Tuesday.

articles.headline: Hundreds of Coal Ash Dumps Lack Regulation
articles.snippet: Most coal byproduct dumps in the U.S. are unregulated, but they contain chemicals that threaten health.
articles.abstract: Most coal byproduct dumps in the U.S. are unregulated, but they contain chemicals that threaten health.
articles.lead_paragraph: The coal ash pond that ruptured and sent a billion gallons of toxic sludge across 300 acres of East Tennessee last month was only one of more than 1,300 similar dumps across the United States — most of them unregulated and unmonitored — that contain billions more gallons of fly ash and other byproducts of burning coal.

articles.headline: Obama Warns of Prospect for Trillion-Dollar Deficits
articles.snippet: Barack Obama sought to distinguish between the need to run big deficits for several years and the need to reduce them later.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama sought to distinguish between the need to run big deficits for several years and the need to reduce them later.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President-elect Barack Obama on Tuesday braced Americans for the unparalleled prospect of “trillion-dollar deficits for years to come,” a stark assessment of the budgetary outlook that he said would force his administration to impose tighter fiscal discipline on the government.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Edmund L. Andrews

articles.headline: The Costly Compromises of Oil From Sand
articles.snippet: Environmental groups in the U.S. and Canada are pushing for a slowdown to oil sands development.
articles.abstract: Environmental groups in the U.S. and Canada are pushing for a slowdown to oil sands development.
articles.lead_paragraph: OTTAWA — The oil that is extracted from Canadian dirt is being portrayed as saving America from energy dependence on the unstable Middle East, or an environmental catastrophe in the making — depending on the perspective.

articles.headline: For Israel, 2006 Lessons but Old Pitfalls
articles.snippet: Israel is applying the military insight it gained from the 2006 war against Hezbollah in Lebanon, but diplomatic lessons do not seem to have been so well applied.
articles.abstract: Israel is applying the military insight it gained from the 2006 war against Hezbollah in Lebanon, but diplomatic lessons do not seem to have been so well applied.
articles.lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM  This time, Israeli military commanders are leading from the front, not trying to direct the infantry from television screens. This time, the military has clear plans, in stages, drawn up with a year’s preparation. This time, there is no illusion about winning a war only from the air. This time, the military chief of staff has kept his silence in public, all cellphones have been confiscated from Israeli soldiers, and the international press has been kept out of the battlefield.

articles.headline: Austria’s ‘Woman on Wall St.’ and Madoff
articles.snippet: Sonja Kohn, who gathered billions for Bernard L. Madoff from investors in Russia and across Europe, has disappeared from view.
articles.abstract: Sonja Kohn, who gathered billions for Bernard L. Madoff from investors in Russia and across Europe, has disappeared from view.
articles.lead_paragraph: VIENNA — With an aggressive style that stood out in the staid world of Austrian banking even more than her bouffant red wig, Sonja Kohn made few friends gathering billions for Bernard L. Madoff from wealthy investors in Russia and across Europe.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Julia Werdigier

articles.headline: Economists Warm to Government Spending but Debate Its Form
articles.snippet: A debate persists over the most effective form of stimulus and what role tax cuts should play.
articles.abstract: A debate persists over the most effective form of stimulus and what role tax cuts should play.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Frightened by the recession and the credit crisis that produced it, the nation’s mainstream economists are embracing public spending to repair the damage — even those who have long resisted a significant government role in a market system.

articles.headline: Madoff Sent 16 Watches and Jewelry
articles.snippet: Bernard L. Madoff violated his bail agreement by sending jewelry to his friends and family, prosecutors argued.
articles.abstract: Bernard L. Madoff violated his bail agreement by sending jewelry to his friends and family, prosecutors argued.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sixteen watches, including diamond-encrusted timepieces from Tiffany and Cartier. Four diamond brooches. Two sets of cuff links. An emerald ring.
